lines.text: No punishment is too severe for those who love.
"A woman's chastity is a sty in the Devil's eye" IRISH PROVERB

[First lines]
Ladies and Gentlemen, I regret we must now - briefly - speak of hell. Hell is like a cone. At the bottom, the sinners whose torments are nearly over. Above the other hells, nearest the earth, our own inferno devised by the keenest brains and worst prigs in Christendom. This inverted parish is in charge of a Satan who has gradually become more and more human - ever recreated, ever renewed. I was about to say spiritualized. Here our comedy begins.
Satan has a sore eye. It may be a sty. Either he has been in a draft - which is unthinkable in hell - or something alarming has happened on earth.
The marquis's perversions sent voluptuous shudders right up into the archangels' wings and down into the tiniest corners of hell.
Were the problem not so serious, I should find it stimulating.
We must go to the root of the evil, the very sty on our Master's eye.
A young woman's chastity. A monstrous challenge to hell.
Aged 20. Lovely as a rose, intelligent, good physique, nice teeth.
Engaged. And still a virgin. The situation is ticklish. If she marries undefiled the consequences will be disastrous.
I must also stress the danger of precedent. Supposing all her friends follow her example!
The result - law and order, monogamy, even happy marriages!
Let us not exaggerate. Marriage is the solid base of hell - our pièce de résistance.
You are right. What would hell be without marriage?
Where innocence is greatest, evil is nearest.
The day's first torment is here.
Did you recognize her?
No, but you will if you loosen her skirts.
Was she crying?
Crying? Hell, yes. Women live in a storm of tears. They must breathe with gills - for a man chokes in all that salt water.

[to Don Juan]
I've titivated you like an old harlot.
I'm surprised you're not in the arms of some hussy.

[Pulls out a knife]
I am here to kill you.
[Don Juan guides her hand with the knife to his his chest]
You're brave and you play for high stakes.

You give me a thrill of delight. My breast will open as gladly to your dagger as your thighs opened to the sharp blade of my love. Give us this final ecstasy - the one our bodies have not yet tasted. I give my death as I gave my life. Complete this sacrificial act and purify our love for ever.
The flames of silver from your mouth are scorching me.
Your breasts must be freed, I'll help you.
O, I am burning, Don Juan!
I will cool you, free you from your clothes.
I have a proposal. You can accept or refuse. Only hell seriously practices free will.
With young women's chastity, the angels are incredibly naive.
The Nordic woman is passionate, surprising and independent. Loyal and romantic, but ruthless in her emotions.
She often has cold feet.
To confuse her unashamed nakedness with levity would be to underestimate her.
She is inexperienced but curious. In the summer she's easy to access because she wears less clothes.
She is seldom aware of her femininity and therefore easily trapped.
Her morals are unfathomable so she's hard to retain.

Some people think God is dead or has never existed, heaven empty and eternity out of reach. They say evil functions as coldly as other natural laws and good is one of mankind's most inexplicable perversions.
My life is a series of fortunate misfortunes. It's as if the devil and his crew put their tails between their legs when I appear.
Why do you blow down my neck?
You have an unusually ugly nose. It reminds me of something.
And you have a peculiar mouth, which reminds me of something.

Offer resistance, if you like. It heightens our pleasure. No, don't say anything - I can read your eyes. Your prudence, character, affectionate nature - your frail health - all forbid you to abandon yourself to passion... But there's a dark spot in your nature, Renata. A flood of sensuality dammed up for too long. Only in your dreams do you let it loose.
In your dreams you wallow in voluptuousness to the very limit of pain and shame.
He's good at math too. Works out anything with his slide-rule.
Has Jonas no faults?
He's a noisy eater and dislikes washing his feet. If those are faults.
You've made a good choice.
Shut your eyes! Now describe me.
Blue eyes. Fair hair. Charming nose, a mouth for kisses, high breasts, rounded hips, all made for love...
It's so tempting. Men almost ask for it. They *want* you to lie to them.
Principles are more sacred than life.
Lack of principle is my principle, vice my virtue, debauchery my asceticism, godlessness my religion.
You must love to know love.
Those capable of love are very few. Their suffering has no limit. I am told they are mirrors which reflect God and make life easier for us wretches in the dark.
Life is a stupid comedy.
Think of little Pablo. Even I am a child of woman and my mother wept over my sins. She showed me real tenderness.
Come here! You've no shame in appealing to my maternal instincts?
No.
You've done a rare thing - touched my heart.

[Repeated line]
*Most* interesting.
I'm not one of those gay devils who buy souls and deal in gold. I'm a trouble-maker.
Nothing is so attractive as evil moments.

No? Won't you open? To see clearly, to understand, see abomination, animal lust, get a poisonous bite in your soul to make you human. You who have *played* your way through life believing good of everyone. Open the door and see infidelity in its stinking bloom.
You're a damned milksop.
Tell me more, my cockalorum.
I shall profit by your knowledge. And good will come of it, not evil.
You devil!
Now, no grumbling and no moping. Be a good boy and I'll pray for you to get to heaven.
How can you be so spiteful, you a parson?
You flatter me.
You can do what you like with me.
I can't endure your suffering - it torments me more than anything I've known. I beg you to free me from your suffering.
Been asleep?
I've both slept and dreamt.
So devils have dreams?
Only nightmares, vicar. For other people, that is.
You have a daughter, a rose of Sharon, a virgin among the earthly fleashpots...
Could we start over again?
No. I don't think so.
Can we change?
We can try.
What else?

Great festivity... No, the young woman is not there. Wherever can she be? No, she's not there. Now I hear her. She's laughing. A young man is breathing heavily on her. She tries to speak, but he stifles her words with kisses.
What do you hear now?
It's quiet, your grace. Ah, now! I hear a bed... the rustle of clothes... But it may be an auditory illusion. Now I hear her breathing fast, like this...
What do you hear?
She is panting. Now it's silent. Quite silent. Now she gave a cry, but not as if it hurt - I can't describe that cry - you gentlemen may know what I mean. Now she's weeping, but not from grief...
Perhaps happiness?

[Final lines]
May I kiss you now?
Yes, but gently.
